Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Development of a Semantic Search Engine Using Natural Language Processing to Generate Validated Technique-Based Recommendations for Life Science Research Methodology
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to advance the development of an artificial intelligence (AI)-supported search engine that facilitates reproducibility and efficiency in life science research. Development of the proposed technology will allow researchers to quickly access unbiased recommendations on techniques and products to advance scientific discovery. By streamlining the literature search process and optimizing research at the experimental design stage, researchers are able to avoid lengthy trial-and-error in the laboratory and accelerate productive experiments. By providing researchers with literature-supported and relevant experimental recommendations within minutes, the proposed search engine can spare researchers time and resources spent on experimental methods poorly suited to their research goals, while also enabling researchers to explore promising methods potentially outside their standard operations.

This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project seeks to address the persistent problems of experimental inefficiency and irreproducibility that slow life sciences research. Phase I efforts will advance the development and evaluation of a proof-of-concept search engine for recommendation of techniques associated with antibodies, a filter mechanism capable of refining search results, and automatically generated graphical analytics presenting key data on technique usage. Leveraging machine learning and Natural Language Processing (NLP) to scan the entire body of peer-reviewed literature and extract data relevant to technique-based search terms, search outputs will accordingly rank antibodies and protocol conditions. To filter results, constraints, such as access to equipment or target genes, will be imposed through development of NLP algorithms capable of identifying relevant contextual information indicating conformance to imposed criteria. Accuracy and relevance of the developed platform's search results will be compared to a popular research-based search engine and is expected to demonstrate highly refined search outputs and recommendations, supporting improved experimental design.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This SBIR Phase I project aimed to demonstrate how an advanced technique-based AI search engine could be used to mine online scientific libraries to identify validated methods, techniques, and products for use in scientific research.

Given the online library of approximately 30M+ peer-reviewed publications, scientists are tasked with sorting through an immense pool of resources and techniques during the experiment design stage. This has resulted in significant issues regarding project reproducibility; without consensus over validated research techniques, scientists are forced not only to comb through an extensive corpus of literature for information, but subject themselves to cost- and time-inefficient trial and error processes that impede scientific discovery and progress. Thus, there is a need for technology that can efficiently sift through the growing body of scientific literature and identify information that will help guide validated, data-driven scientific research and decision-making.

This project establishes a novel science search engine platform through which scientists can easily locate scientific literature pertinent to their areas of research, bypassing conventional search methods. Through machine learning (ML) and natural language processing (NLP), this technology platform provides scientists with an automated method to comprehensively assess scientific literature based on the type of research to be conducted. The technology also utilizes interactive graphics to provide users with relevant insight and a more specific results search. The output of searches using this platform is designed to provide scientists with a detailed examination of validated methods, techniques, and products and how they might be used together to best fit a scientist's or laboratory's proposed research. This process has the potential to eliminate manual literature searches while providing a more comprehensive summary of methods and techniques needed to perform optimal laboratory research, eliminating drawn-out trial and error processes and saving laboratories time and funding as a result.

In this project, a technique-based search engine was established capable of identifying scientific literature to guide the design of scientific experiments. Our experiment focused on antibody literature, as this represents a research field with critically inconsistent methodology. We utilized ML, NLP, deep neural networks, and semantic search tools to effectively train our algorithms to 1) recognize publications that used antibody-related techniques, 2) characterize relationships between key object-tuples to draw out information on techniques, uses, antibodies, protocol conditions, etc., and 3) score technique-use pairings based on a variety of factors, each assigned factor weights to properly account for their influence on method validation. We ended up with an antibody-associated library of publications covering 1,030,165 products, 3,207,918 article snippets, and 1,027,094 images. We focused on developing filters to allow users to filter by technique or product, as well as by disease (e.g., COVID), gene, or assay ID. We also developed graphics displaying key metrics for users (i.e., researchers) and customers (i.e., vendors and suppliers/distributors). Finally, we compared the Bioz platform search results to those found on Google Scholar using independent evaluators. Our results showed that the Bioz platform had significantly higher results regarding relevant content of scientific literature compared to Google Scholar. These results indicate the robust nature of this technique-based search engine and supporting future efforts to expand the platform to hypothesis-based searches.
